that works with the clock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e@sinonjs/fake-timers\u003c/code\u003e can be used to simulate passing time in automated tests and other\nsituations time. This means that there is no need to \u003ccode\u003etick()\u003c/code\u003e the\nclock in a situation where you won't know \u003cstrong\u003ewhen\u003c/strong\u003e to call \u003ccode\u003etick()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePlease note that this is achieved using the original setImmediate() API at a certain\nconfigurable interval \u003ccode\u003econfig.advanceTimeDelta\u003c/code\u003e (default: 20ms). Meaning time would\nbe incremented every 20ms, not in real time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAn example would be:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"var FakeTimers = require(\u0026quot;@sinonjs/fake-timers\u0026quot;);\nvar clock = FakeTimers.install({\n    shouldAdvanceTime: true,\n    advanceTimeDelta: 40,\n});\n\nsetTimeout(() =\u0026gt; {\n    console.log(\u0026quot;this just timed out\u0026quot;); //executed after 40ms\n}, 30);\n\nsetImmediate(() =\u0026gt; {\n    console.log(\u0026quot;not so immediate\u0026quot;); //executed after 40ms\n});\n\nsetTimeout(() =\u0026gt; {\n    console.log(\u0026quot;this timed out after\u0026quot;); //executed after 80ms\n    clock.uninstall();\n}, 50);\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003evar\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan \u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e on the global scope).\nNote that in NodeJS also the \u003ca href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/timers.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etimers\u003c/a\u003e module will receive fake timers when using global scope.\nThe following configuration options are available\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable\u003e\n\u003cthead\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eParameter\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eType\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDefault\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003cth\u003eDescription\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/thead\u003e\n\u003ctbody\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.now\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eNumber/Date\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e0\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003einstalls FakeTimers with the specified unix epoch\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.toFake\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eString[]\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e[\"setTimeout\", \"clearTimeout\", \"setImmediate\", \"clearImmediate\",\"setInterval\", \"clearInterval\", \"Date\", \"requestAnimationFrame\", \"cancelAnimationFrame\", \"requestIdleCallback\", \"cancelIdleCallback\", \"hrtime\", \"performance\"]\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003ean array with explicit function names (or objects, in the case of \"performance\") to hijack. \u003cem\u003eWhen not set, FakeTimers will automatically fake all methods \u003cstrong\u003eexcept\u003c/strong\u003e \u003ccode\u003enextTick\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/em\u003e e.g., \u003ccode\u003eFakeTimers.install({ toFake: [\"setTimeout\",\"nextTick\"]})\u003c/code\u003e will fake only \u003ccode\u003esetTimeout\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003enextTick\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.loopLimit\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eNumber\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e1000\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003ethe maximum number of timers that will be run when calling runAll()\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.shouldAdvanceTime\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eBoolean\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003efalse\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003etells FakeTimers to increment mocked time automatically based on the real system time shift (e.g. the mocked time will be incremented by 20ms for every 20ms change in the real system time)\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.advanceTimeDelta\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eNumber\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e20\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003erelevant only when using with \u003ccode\u003eshouldAdvanceTime: true\u003c/code\u003e. increment mocked time by \u003ccode\u003eadvanceTimeDelta\u003c/code\u003e ms every \u003ccode\u003eadvanceTimeDelta\u003c/code\u003e ms change in the real system time.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003e\u003ccode\u003econfig.shouldClearNativeTimers\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003eBoolean\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003efalse\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003ctd\u003etells FakeTimers to clear 'native' (i.e. not fake) timers by delegating to their respective handlers. These are not cleared by default, leading to potentially unexpected behavior if timers existed prior to installing FakeTimers.\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/tbody\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003evar id = clock.setTimeout(callback, timeout)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-var-id--clocksettimeoutcallback-timeout\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: var id = clock.setTimeout(callback, timeout)\" href=\"#var-id--clocksettimeoutcallback-timeout\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSchedules the callback to be fired once \u003ccode\u003etimeout\u003c/code\u003e milliseconds have ticked by.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn Node.js \u003ccode\u003esetTimeout\u003c/code\u003e returns a timer object. If new timers are added while it is executing they will be run as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis makes it easier to run asynchronous tests to completion without worrying about the number of timers they use, or the delays in those timers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt runs a maximum of \u003ccode\u003eloopLimit\u003c/code\u003e times after which it assumes there is an infinite loop of timers and throws an error.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003erunAllAsync()\u003c/code\u003e will also break the event loop, allowing any scheduled promise\ncallbacks to execute \u003cem\u003ebefore\u003c/em\u003e running the timers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" alt="Contributor Covenant" data-canonical-src="https://img.shields.io/badge/Contributor%20Covenant-v2.0%20adopted-ff69b4.svg" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">JavaScript implementation of the timer APIs; <code>setTimeout</code>, <code>clearTimeout</code>, <code>setImmediate</code>, <code>clearImmediate</code>, <code>setInterval</code>, <code>clearInterval</code>, <code>requestAnimationFrame</code>, <code>cancelAnimationFrame</code>, <code>requestIdleCallback</code>, and <code>cancelIdleCallback</code>, along with a clock instance that controls the flow of time. FakeTimers also provides a <code>Date</code> implementation that gets its time from the clock.</p><p dir="auto">In addition in browser environment <code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> provides a <code>performance</code> implementation that gets its time from the clock. In Node environments FakeTimers provides a <code>nextTick</code> implementation that is synchronized with the clock - and a <code>process.hrtime</code> shim that works with the clock.</p><p dir="auto"><code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> can be used to simulate passing time in automated tests and othersituations where you want the scheduling semantics, but don't want to actuallywait.</p><p dir="auto"><code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> is extracted from <a href="https://github.com/sinonjs/sinon.js">Sinon.JS</a> and targets the <a href="https://sinonjs.org/releases/latest/#supported-runtimes" rel="nofollow">same runtimes</a>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Autocomplete, IntelliSense and TypeScript definitions</h2><a id="user-content-autocomplete-intellisense-and-typescript-definitions" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Autocomplete, IntelliSense and TypeScript definitions" href="#autocomplete-intellisense-and-typescript-definitions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Version 7 introduced JSDoc to the codebase. This should provide autocomplete and type suggestions in supporting IDEs. If you need more elaborate type support, TypeScript definitions for the Sinon projects are independently maintained by the Definitely Types community:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="npm install -D @types/sinonjs__fake-timers"><pre class="notranslate"><code>npm install -D @types/sinonjs__fake-timers</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Installation</h2><a id="user-content-installation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Installation" href="#installation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto"><code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> can be used in both Node and browser environments. Installation is as easy as</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="npm install @sinonjs/fake-timers"><pre>npm install @sinonjs/fake-timers</pre></div><p dir="auto">If you want to use <code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> in a browser you can either build your own bundle or use <a href="https://www.skypack.dev" rel="nofollow">Skypack</a>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Usage</h2><a id="user-content-usage" new clock, schedule events on it using the timerfunctions and pass time using the <code>tick</code> method.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" If you want to simulate asynchronous behavior, please see the <code>async</code> function variants (eg <code>clock.tick(time)</code> vs <code>await clock.tickAsync(time)</code>).</p><p dir="auto">The <code>next</code>, <code>runAll</code>, <code>runToFrame</code>, and <code>runToLast</code> methods are available to advance the clock. See theAPI Reference for more details.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Faking the native timers</h3><a id="user-content-faking-the-native-timers" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Faking the native timers" href="#faking-the-native-timers"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When using <code>@sinonjs/fake-timers</code> to test timers, you will most likely want to replace the nativetimers such that calling <code>setTimeout</code> actually schedules a callback with yourclock instance, not the browser's internals.</p><p dir="auto">Calling <code>install</code> with no arguments achieves this. You can call <code>uninstall</code>later to restore things as they were again.Note that in NodeJS also the <a href="https://nodejs.org/api/timers.html" rel="nofollow">timers</a> module will receive fake timers when using global scope.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// In the browser global !== "undefined" ? global : window);setTimeout(fn, 15); // Schedules with clock.setTimeoutclock.uninstall();// setTimeout is restored to the native implementation"><pre><span class="pl-c">// In implementation</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">To hijack timers in another context pass it to the <code>install</code> method.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate This means that there is no need to <code>tick()</code> theclock in a situation where you won't know <strong>when</strong> to call <code>tick()</code>.</p><p dir="auto">Please note that this is achieved using the original setImmediate() API at a certainconfigurable interval <code>config.advanceTimeDelta</code> (default: 20ms). Only available in environments that support the Performance object (browsers mostly).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>FakeTimers.withGlobal</code></h3><a id="user-content-faketimerswithglobal" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: FakeTimers.withGlobal" href="#faketimerswithglobal"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In order to support creating clocks based on separate or sandboxed environments (such as JSDOM), FakeTimers exports a factory method which takes single argument <code>global</code>, which it inspects to figure out what to mock and what features to support. When invoking this function with a global, you will get back an object with <code>timers</code>, <code>createClock</code> and <code>install</code> - same as the regular FakeTimers exports only based on the passed in global instead of the global environment.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Running tests</h2><a id="user-content-running-tests" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Running tests" href="#running-tests"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">FakeTimers has a comprehensive test suite. If you're thinking of contributing bugfixes or suggesting new features, you need to make sure you have not broken anytests.
